name: hard coal, import from RU | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18282/documentation

This dataset describes the transport needed for an average export of hard coal from Russia to China. The transport within Russia is covered in the hard coal market, RU dataset. About 45% of Russian coal is consumed domestically, the rest is exported to Europe and Asia. The major coal ports are Murmansk, Ust-Luga, and Tuapse in the West for exports to Europe; Vanino and Vostochny in the East to handle exports to Asia. ;Dust from transport and load/unload operations is included. Trade volumes are based on 2015 import data according to the United Nations (comtrade.org).;;Note: Discrepancies of hard coal trade volumes between different statistical sources as well as between import and export statistics of the same source are primarily due to differences in coal classification methodologies, which are not uniform on a global basis. They also occur because of coal in-transit, coal that is unaccounted for, and reporting discrepancies by importing and exporting countries.

Starting at the gate of the hard coal mine, this dataset includes the transport, re-loading and storage specific to coal exports/imports in the respective geographies. This means it includes 1.) any transport between the hard coal mine and the border of the exporting country which is required in addition to the transport needs of the domestic “market for hard coal”, 2.) the transport through transit countries (if applicable), 3.) the transoceanic freight shipping (if applicable) and 4.) any transport between the border of the importing country and the consumers which is required in addition to the transport needs of the domestic coal market.


The activity ends with the delivery of hard coal to the domestic market of the importing country.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The trade volumes represented in this dataset are based on 2015 UN trade statistics retrieved online from comtrade.org.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This datasets models the import of hard coal from Russia to China.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Transport of hard coal by train and transoceanic ship.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature research. The trade volumes were retrieved from UN statistics at comtrade.org for the commodity codes 270111 (Coal; anthracite, whether or not pulverised, but not agglomerated), 270112 (Coal; bituminous, whether or not pulverised, but not agglomerated), 270119 (Coal; (other than anthracite and bituminous), whether or not pulverised but not agglomerated.

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description:
The main Russian mining area is located in the Kuzbass basin in Central Russia. About 45% of coal is consumed domestically, the rest is exported to Europe and Asia. Domestic consumers, mostly power plants are located both in direct vicinity to the mines as well as in the far east and west of the country. Long-distance transport typically ranges between 800-2000km (Walker, 2000), while power plants at the mines hardly require transport. We therefore estimate the average distance at the lower end of the long-distance range, namely 800km. Due to the long transport distances coal in Russia is commonly transported via rail. Average distances to the major exporting ports is estimated to be at the higher end of the long-distance range, namely 2000km. The balance between 800km and 2000km is required by export coal only and thus covered in the “hard coal, import from RU” datasets. The main ports for coal are: Murmansk, Ust-Luga, and Tuapse in the West for exports to Europe; Vanino and Vostochny in the East to handle exports to Asia (IEA, 2017).
Dust from transport and load/unload operations is included. Average coal losses are considered. Average emissions to water due to leaching from coal heaps at storage is estimated from the literature.
Reference(s): IEA. 2017. Country Analysis Brief: Russia. Accessed online at: <https://www.eia.gov/beta/international/analysis_includes/countries_long/Russia/russia.pdf>,
Walker, S., 2000. Major coalfields of the world. ISBN: 929029342X 9789290293422.

exchanges.description:
For a lack of more recent or specific data this value is based on the estimation by Dones et al. (2007) that generally 0.2% of losses occure during coal transport. It is assumed that these losses are released to the environment in the form of particulate matter > 10 micrometer. Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

Rough estimate using Google Earth and freight shipping maps. The major Russian coal ports are Murmansk, Ust-Luga, and Tuapse in the West for exports to Europe; Vanino and Vostochny in the East to handle exports to Asia, among others to the ports of Qingdao, Tianjin, Caofeidan, Fangchen, Ningbo and directly to power plants (IEA, 2017). An average distance for sea transport of 2000km was estimated.
Reference(s): IEA. 2017. Country Analysis Brief: Russia. Accessed online at: https://www.eia.gov/beta/international/analysis_includes/countries_long/Russia/russia.pdf, 15 November 2017(opensea.org, 2017)

exchanges.description:
Compensation for product losses. For a lack of more recent or specific data this value is based on the estimation by Dones et al. (2007) that generally 0.2% of losses occure during coal transport. It is assumed that these losses are released to the environment in the form of particulate matter > 10 micrometer. Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
